awd_titl_txt: Ethical Standards and Practices of Environmental Science Teams: Does Team Diversity Matter?
awd_abstract_narration:
Today, most scientific research is done by scientists working together in teams, and many current social problems are so complicated that they require large, interdisciplinary teams of scientists. But, it is not always obvious who the best scientists are to include in a team and whether teams with certain types of scientists have different behaviors or practices than teams with other types of scientists. This project is studying whether teams with different team composition have different behaviors and practices. Some research shows that team composition (such as the gender, ethnicity, or discipline of the team members; also called team diversity) influences science outcomes such as effectiveness and productivity. But, there is little research that examines how team diversity affects scientists' ethical behavior, which is the focus of this study. The ethical behavior of scientists matters because it can determine the quality of the science that gets done, and it can influence the trust that society places in scientists.  To answer this question, the awardee will measure team diversity and determine how it affects ethical behaviors related to materials sharing, authorship, and mentoring. It is expected that scientists who work in more diverse teams (e.g., those that include women, members of racial or ethnic minority groups, or individuals from different disciplinary backgrounds) may promote team cultures that include social sensitivity and ideals of community welfare. Therefore, higher team diversity may advance science's effectiveness by promoting more ethical standards and practices.  

This project will conduct both qualitative and quantitative surveys of individuals who are part of teams in three NSF programs that fund highly collaborative research: Dimensions of Biodiversity, Dynamics of Coupled Natural and Human Systems, and Macrosystems Biology. The project will first perform qualitative interviews on a subset of individuals working in teams funded by these three NSF programs to develop more precise hypotheses about the relationships between team diversity and ethical behaviors.  Then, those hypotheses will be tested using a quantitative survey administered to the remainder of the funded teams. The quantitative survey responses will be analyzed using multilevel mediation modeling that accounts for the nested nature of the data (i.e., individuals nested within teams) and that can determine relationships between team diversity and ethical behaviors as well as the factors mediating those relationships. In addition to sharing study results, the project team will develop and facilitate workshops to help interdisciplinary environmental scientists recognize the effects of diversity on ethical standards and practices and facilitate increased diversity within teams.

por.por_cntn:
Today, most scientific research is done by scientists working together in teams, and many current social problems are so complicated that they require large, interdisciplinary teams of scientists to effectively address them. However, while bringing together diverse teams of scientists can promote creativity and increase the relevance of research, it can also generate challenges, especially for team members who contribute to team diversity. The goal of this project was to contribute to the development of more effective and diverse science teams by developing a better understanding of how the characteristics of interdisciplinary science teams influence team practices and the experiences of team members.

Our project included in-depth interviews and a survey of interdisciplinary science teams, both of which were funded by the National Science Foundation. We conducted interviews with participants from 6 teams and a survey of 266 scientists from 105 teams. We characterized the diversity of the teams both in terms of their demographics (e.g., gender, race, ethnicity) and their scientific backgrounds (e.g., disciplines, length of career, and duration on the team). We also collected information about the climate on the teams (i.e., their norms, attitudes, and expectations) and the practices of the teams with respect to assigning authorship on published papers, sharing data, and mentoring team members.

From interviews, we identified a form of honorary authorship (i.e., listing individuals as authors even though they did not make substantial contributions to a paper) motivated by the desire to include all or many team members on publications. We found that some early-career team members with less power and status on teams perceived negative impacts from this practice, and thus it has the potential to undermine true inclusion from underrepresented groups.  

From survey responses, we found a positive association between team members' perceptions of the climate on their teams and their overall satisfaction with the teams, their perceptions of the amount of data sharing that occurred, and their satisfaction with authorship and mentoring practices on the teams. In other words, when team members perceived their teams as being collaborative and inclusive, they also tended to be more satisfied with their team overall and with the team's practices involving authorship, data sharing, and mentoring. We also found that teams with more demographic diversity were perceived as having a more positive climate than those with less demographic diversity. However, and importantly, individuals from underrepresented groups tended to perceive team climate more negatively. In keeping with these results, we specifically found that LGBTQ scientists were less likely than cisgender-heterosexual scientists to experience positive interpersonal climates in their teams, and these more negative team climate experiences were related to more negative professional outcomes associated with authorship experiences and professional respect. We also found that some aspects of team climate were more significantly related to mentoring satisfaction for people of color than for White people, suggesting that people of color might have been particularly attentive to cues indicating whether they belonged and were valued. Taken together, all these results suggest that although it is valuable to create demographically diverse science teams, it is important to address barriers to the full inclusion and support of those from underrepresented groups.

In addition to publishing our findings in academic journals, we also shared our findings with the scientific community in the form of workshops that we gave at academic conferences and at multiple universities. These workshops provided an opportunity to discuss the challenges that people with less power (e.g., early-career scientists and those from minoritized groups) face in receiving adequate credit for their roles on scientific papers. We also produced a case study, “Ethics & Team Power Dynamics in Authorship Decisions,” which is available at the Online Ethics Center (onlineethics.org) as a resource for students and research teams. Finally, building on our finding that team climate plays an important role in science teams, we were awarded a new grant from the National Science Foundation, “Broadening Participation of Underrepresented Scholars in Academic STEM: The Influence of an Inclusive Climate on Early-Career Outcomes.” With this new project, we hope to better understand how the climate in four scientific disciplines and more than 120 U.S. departments affects career outcomes for underrepresented scholars.
